header.matter: Assault/Torture of detained political activists in police holding cells on Fountains Street, Bloem.

testimony:
(cont)
	Now Mr Bokaba, at the end of the proceedings last week we were at the stage where I was asking you to give explanations of how Ngo could have known of your activities, those of Selahla and of Loots and we'll proceed from there.
	During which stage between '87 and 1989 did Ngo approach you and say to you that he wanted to join security branch?
Let me put it shortly.  I said that it was early 1987, somewhere in February, if I remember well.

Now in that case, how could Ngo have known that throughout the entire period '87 up to '89 Loots was the officer commanding?  Let me put it this way, how could he have known that you were reporting to Loots all the time - that things would not have changed?
I've explained that Ngo could have known because I took him for an interview to Captain Loots.
The point counsel makes is that you took him for an interview in early in February 1987, that wouldn't give him no indication at all that Loots remained in that job in 1988 and 1989, would it?
I understand that he could have known Sir, because he knew that Loots was the commanding officer.
Now, on your version, he saw Loots only once, is that correct? And he never saw him again.
Now, you do not dispute that the house of Louisa Mbongo was burnt down, isn't it?
I don't dispute that fact Sir.
And you also do not dispute that it was burnt down by Ngo and Selahla?
By whom was the house burnt on your version?
It was himself, by himself.  I'm not saying it is him, I'm saying there is a probability that it is him if it was burnt.
Why would it be Ngo alone?
He's the one who knows that the house was burnt.
And he also knows that Selahla was present when he burnt the house?
How can you dispute that Selahla was present when the house was burnt down?
I'm saying Selahla denies that also.
I don't know how to answer that question because I'm explaining that Selahla also didn't dispute - he doesn't know that.
As far as you're concerned, do you dispute - do you say Selahla was not involved in the burning down of the house of Louisa Mbongo?
I say he was not there.
How do you know that he was not there?
He has told us twice that Selahla disputes that he was there.  I take it that's why he says Selahla was not there.  Did you believe Selahla when he said he was - he denied that he was there?
Now, why do you believe Selahla when he denies that he was not present?
Mr Chairman, I want to object against that question.
This was a policeman who worked with him as a unit for how many years?
You can say about three Sir.
Isn't that a fairly obvious reason why he believes him - they worked together?
I don't think the matter is that simple Sir.  He must tell us, the evidence must come from him why he believes him when he says that he was not present when the house was burnt down.
I worked with Selahla in Mamelodi.
Were you with Selahla at all times during '87 to '89?

In many instances I was with him and I believe that if he is called to testify before this Commission, he's going to say exactly what I'm saying - that he was - he didn't work with Ngo and he didn't burn the house with Ngo.
And you obviously dispute that you were involved in the burning of the house?
Yes, I dispute that - I didn't burn anybody's house during my work as a policeman.
And did you not dispute that Nono Gint's house was burnt down?
I dispute that, I don't know that.
You don't know if whether the house was burnt down or not?
I don't that house, I don't know as whether it was burnt.

And you can't dispute that it was burnt by Ngo and
Selahla?
He doesn't know if it was burnt.

Mr Chairman, furthermore the version was not that it was burnt only by Selahla and Ngo but Mr Ngo's version is that Captain Bokaba was present as well, now my learned friend is putting a version which is not even his own client's version.
I think that's a fair objection.  You're putting that it was burnt by two people ...[intervention]
...[inaudible] Your client's version is that it was burnt by three people.

It is obvious that he disputes that he was involved and what I'm putting to him is that he can only deny that he was not involved but cannot deny that Selahla was also involved.
	Now, can you deny that the house was burnt down by Ngo and Selahla?
Let me answer you this way, I don't know.

Is this getting anywhere when he says he doesn't know anything about it?  His original answer was he didn't know if this house was burnt down or not.  What is the point of putting more
questions - to try to get what answer?  I don't know?
As the Chair pleases.  Now you cannot dispute - you do not dispute that Louisa Mbongo was  member of MAYO, do you?
I don't know Louisa whether she was a member of MAYO or not, I don't know.

And you do not dispute that her house was burnt down as a result of the fact that Nono, I beg your pardon - you do not dispute the fact that her house was burnt down as a result of the fact that she organised a sympathy protest against the burning house of the - against the burning of the house of Louisa Mbongo?
I don't know Nono Gint's.  I don't know Nono Gint's house.  I don't know as whether her house was burnt and again I don't know as whether there was such kind of a protest march.
And this house - these houses were petrol-bombed.  Now, you also do not dispute that obviously, do you?
I know - I know nothing about those houses.  Those are the allegations made by your client.
Now ordinarily, houses were petrol-bombed in the course of political conflict, do you dispute that?
May you please repeat your question Sir.
Ordinarily, house were petrol-bombed in the course of political conflict.
May you repeat your question Sir?
Mr Chairman, is my learned friend putting that as a fact - is there going to be evidence before this Committee about that?  I object against the question.
Well, it hasn't been put in the form of a question, it's been put in a form of a statement.  What you've said to him is, ordinarily houses are burnt - it's part of a political ...[intervention]
And I've asked him whether he disputes that or he doesn't.
Do you say that I dispute that houses were burnt during the political unrest?

No, he's asking you whether houses ordinarily, were burnt in the course of political unrest - petrol-bombed in the course of a political unrest or do you know of any other cause why houses were petrol-bombed?
Does he speak specifically about the houses which his client alleges that they were burnt of he speaks under general circumstances?
Yes, houses were burnt under general circumstances.
Why?  Because of political unrest or because of other reasons?
Let me answer that question in this way.
We're waiting for the complete answer Sir.
During the time of unrest, some of the houses were burnt because of political reasons.

Mr Chairman, I just want to make the point that on page 45 of bundle A, Mr Ngo himself has said that he burnt a house because of a personal grudge and that application was withdrawn, so the statement made by my learned friend should be qualified for instance by an incident where his own client was involved.
I think he said mainly, didn't he?
That is correct Sir.  Ordinarily, petrol bombs were used in the course of political conflict, isn't it?
Petrol-bombs were used in the township.
But Captain, why do you seem to have difficulty with dealing with what you understand to be the essence of the creation, that these petrol bombs were used in political - in the political context.
I don't dispute that, I explained.  I explained to you that petrol bombs were used to burn houses in the township generally in the township.  That's how I answered your question.
But what I'm putting to you is that ordinarily petrol bombs were used in the course of political conflict.
That is so, at times they were burnt because of personal grudges.
Now, which incidents do you know of where houses were petrol-bombed because of personal grudges?
Should I explain specific houses and the owners of those houses?
Then I don't know those houses which were burnt because of personal grudges.
And you only know about the one which Ngo refers to in his applications, in his application?
I don't know even that, that's how explained that incident.
Now, where houses were petrol bombed, security branch would have had an interest in the circumstances leading to the arson, wouldn't it?
May you please explain your question Sir?  Put your question clearly Sir.
What is it that you don't understand about the question?
I'm asking you to repeat the question.
The question is simple.  Where petrol bombs were used in the course of arson, security branch would have an interest in the matter?
What kind of interest are you talking about?
But Captain, you are a Captain you know ...[intervention]

What he's trying to avoid is the suggestion that by "interest", you mean they may have participated in the petrol-bombing.  What you in fact mean - as I understand it, you mean they would have had an interest in investigating the matter.
If you could perhaps make that  clear to him because your client's version is that the security police did all the bombing.
As the Chair pleases.   Where houses were petrol-bombed, security branch would have an interest in the matter in the sense that they would have cause to investigate the matter?

Yes, they would investigate but let me explain it this way.  There was a special task team which was stationed in Mamelodi police station.  That special task team was working directly to investigate those kinds of incidents.  Security branch was not part and parcel of the investigative team, those are the people who would
investigate the dockets.
Who was in charge of this team or who were the members of this team?
I don't remember well but let me say this, Director Fikter who is the station commander of Garangu police station, was a member of that special investigative team.

Now, before you brought in the qualification, you conceded that special branch, rather security branch would have an interest in investigating the matter.  In what sense would security branch investigate the matter?
Let me explain it this way Sir, to gather information - if we were able to gather that information that so and so was involved, then we'll pass that information to the special investigative team.

Now, it is obvious that the special investigative team would carry out the investigation insofar as the prosecution is concerned and that security branch would carry out the investigation insofar as the gathering of information relating to security matters is concerned.  Do you dispute that?

Yes, the security branch would gather the information - not to investigate the case and to carry the docket.  They would gather the information and then pass it over to the relevant people or structure, then those people would do the arrest, then they will take those people to court.
And on the other hand, security branch would also detain people on strength of the suspicion that they were involved in incidents like petrol-bombing houses?

To detain people because of taking part in the petrol-bombing was not part and parcel of the security branch, they would only take that information to that task team which I mentioned.  There were a state of emergency where members of the security branch detained people because of the information they were able to gather.
Such as that persons were associated with certain political organisations and could possibly have been responsible for the petrol-bombing of certain houses and other properties?
They would do that because of the information at their disposal.

Now, why do you dissociate yourself from security branch because you were a member of the security branch, why do you say "we arrested them on the strength of such information if we had such information"?   Why do you use the third person?
Let me explain it this way ...[intervention]

I'm afraid I don't understand that question at all.  You're saying to him - he said: "we arrested them on the strength of such investigation", are you suggesting that is the third person when you say "we"?
No, I'm saying that he keeps saying that they would arrest people when they got such information and I'm saying why doesn't he say, we arrested people ...[intervention]

Because as I understand it, he's told us they didn't arrest people, they passed any information they had onto the special unit or to other investigative units.  They didn't do that, they didn't investigate the case and they didn't carry the docket which would mean as I understand it, they didn't effect the arrests.

That was a while ago Sir, later on he said that security branch did arrest people and they would arrest people on the strength of such information, they would detain them under the security branch and this is ...[intervention]
When there was a state of emergency they would detain people.

Yes, and my question to him is that he was a member of the security branch and why does he dissociate himself from these activities? Why doesn't he say, we arrested people or detained people on the strength of such information because he was also a member of
the security branch.
Were your duties - did your duties include arresting people, detaining people?  I'm talking about you now personally.
During the state of emergency yes,  I was one of those people who were detaining people.
And otherwise, when people had committed crimes when it was not during the state of emergency?
It was the work of the special investigative team during the other incidents.
But Mr Bokaba, there was security legislation in terms of which people were detained without trial, which was carried out by the security branch.

You must understand one thing, I started working at the security branch on the 1st of May 1986.  I didn't have a rank then, the highest rank which I had - I was just a mere constable.  If you are going to ask me about a Security Act and then how people were detained and on which Act they were detained, then I'm not going to answer your questions in that regard.

But you know, that legislation was a matter of public knowledge. Since around 1976, it had become common knowledge that there was security legislation in terms of which people could be detained without trial and you were a constable, you should know
about that.
I explained to you that during the state of emergency, we detained people.
Now, the point of my question is that the incident such as the burning down of political activist Louisa Mbongo and Nono Gint's house, would have come to the attention of security branch?
I don't know those houses, I don't know them.
And on your version, you and Selahla were the people primarily responsible for Mamelodi?

I was working in Mamelodi as I explained and together with Dannyboy Selahla and others whom I've explained but the house you speak of them, I don't know them and the people you mentioned like Nono Gint, I don't know them.
And you do not have the slightest idea about these houses?
I don't know them.  Whatever happened to those houses, I don't know.
Is it possible that these things came to your attention but you've forgotten about them?
I don't know them.  I start to know them when you spoke of them.
Do you know of any houses that - in Mamelodi which were bombed by members of the security branch?
Do you know of any houses in Mamelodi which were bombed by members of the security branch?

I know the house - the church which belonged to Legot which is called Legotlo.  I knew that by hearing from Captain Loots - those are the people who took part in the bombing of that church and Scheepers Marudi's house.   I knew later when they were talking, that they were burnt or bombed by the members of the security branch.  I think those are the only houses I know.
Did they tell you it had been bombed by the security branch?
Did they tell you it had been bombed by the security branch?
When did they tell you that?
I heard later from Captain Hechter.
That was after a long time.

Why do you say in your affidavit that
"as far as my knowledge goes, no houses as far as my knowledge goes, were bombed by members of the security branch"

Page, sorry - page 45, para 3.4
"I categorically deny 3.4 that any of the houses where I was supposedly involved as mentioned in his application, were ever bombed by myself or as far as my knowledge goes, by members of the security branch, Northern Transvaal"
You are referring to ...[intervention]
You are referring only to the two houses in question.
The houses mentioned by the applicant.

I explained that I heard later about those houses.  I
think it is after I've already submitted that affidavit.
I understand the context different, I understand you.  I think I must take back my question, I misunderstood the paragraph.

Mr Chairman, may I please just for purposes of the reference to Scheepers Marudi's house just - I know we don't have the applications here but refer you to the applications of Hechter and van Vuuren specifically.  You would have noted that it wasn't dealt with in their evidence but there was a general application made for amnesty for bombing of various - petrol-bombing of various houses - or bombing of various houses of which the details the applicants didn't know about.  I'm just referring for purposes of the reference to this bombing, to those applications.
Well Hechter specifically - I think he mentioned specific - he didn't know the addresses but with regard two houses, he actually gave the details as to who he was with.

Yes, he gave details of those he could remember but you will see in the applications, there was a general schedule referring to petrol-bombing of other house of which they couldn't remember the details.  I'm just making that point Mr Chairman.
Now, you have applied for amnesty haven't you?
That's correct, I think that's why we're here.  ...[inaudible]
And for what acts have you applied for amnesty?
The same person called Scheepers Marudi.

And then also for murder where I was present when that murder happened.  I don't remember the identity or the names of those people but the person I remember among those people, the other one is Patrick Maake - M-a-a-k-e, the other person is Sefola - S-e-f-o-l-a.   I don't remember the third one.  Then I don't remember the other person again - the other victim.  I've applied amnesty for three cases.
Now, where did these incidents take place?

Let me say it this way, the assault happened after the person was arrested in Mamelodi, then it happened at Compal Building.  And then the murder, the one person was arrested in Mamelodi.  I think it's Maake or Sefola or - that is Makupi.  I don't remember well but the other one was arrested in Witbank...

Mr Chairman, before we go into all the detail of
where Makupi and Maake and Sefola were arrested and where they were taken, I have the amnesty application of Captain Bokaba in front of me.  You have heard evidence about this incident.  The evidence in his application accords with the evidence you have heard.  The place was Hammanskraal, close to Pienaars Rivier ...[intervention]
You would remember that.  And then ...[intervention]

Just one second Sir, I think these questions are asked for my benefit as well and when he - you know, if he wants to clarify these matters, he must make me follow what he is saying.  I don't know where Hammanskraal comes in for instance.

But Mr Chairman, with respect, we are going into the details of those incidents as well now.  My learned friend doesn't know the contents of those applications and if he's going to ask Captain Bokaba about those incidents and how it happened, we'll have to go into the exact detail of how Maake was abducted in Mamelodi, how Makupi was abducted, how Sefola was abducted, how it happened, where they were taken etc.
	What I'm trying to place before the Committee is something that you have heard in evidence before of other applicants and that is that this incident happened in Hammanskraal according to the amnesty 
application of Captain Bokaba and the other incident ...[intervention]
Which incident happened in Hammanskraal, that's my question?
The incident, Makupi, Sefola and Maake.  That was the one incident ...[intervention]

Yes, the murder, the murder.  The murder happened there.  And then there was the murder of the unknown ANC cadre which you also have heard evidence of Captain van Vuuren and Captain Hechter and that took place in Boputhatswana.
You see the difficulty now is that you're giving a different account of what he's told us ...[intervention}
May we ask you for a moment, the applicant cannot hear - maybe it's because of the earphones.

Mr Chairman, and furthermore I object against these questions, I don't know what the relevance of the questions are.  I don't know what it has to do with Mr Ngo's application, how does it fit in with Mr Ngo's application - really it escapes me.

As I understand since it's the only reason why it would be relevant is that he hopes to get some information from here about acts which Ngo also gave evidence about, acts which Ngo was also concerned in.  Is that not so Mr Memani?

Mr Chairman, acts where Mr Ngo were involved in which he didn't apply for amnesty for, because the acts referred to in the amnesty application of Captain Bokaba according to Mr Ngo, he wasn't present but as far as my learned friend wants to create that impression before the Committee and prejudice his client's case, then he can go ahead.
Now, you told us that these people were arrested in Mamelodi, is that correct?
I said not all of them were arrested in Mamelodi, not all of them were arrested from Mamelodi.
Now, who was arrested in Mamelodi?
I said to you that's Scheepers Marudi and the other person whom I cannot remember and then Maake.  I don't know as well if it's Makupi or - but one of them has been arrested from Witbank.
And these people were associated with activities in Mamelodi?
Do you want me to explain the cases in detail or what?

I think the question is,  these people were political activists in Mamelodi engaged in some - in political activities of some
kind in the area of Mamelodi where you worked.
Yes, Scheepers Marudi was an activist in Mamelodi.  I think Makupe and Maake were activists in Mamelodi.
Was Mr Ngo involved in any of these incidents, the arrest of Maake or Sefola or Makupi or Scheepers Marudi?
I thank you for that question because I was asking myself that question, that if Ngo was working with me, I believe that he could have made an application for amnesty in regard to those acts.
I'm only asking you whether he was involved, yes or no?  And if we could ...[intervention]
If we could get straight answers we'll shorten the proceedings in the interest of the whole of South Africa and the taxpayers.
The two of you were both involved.
Did you get your commands from Loots to do these things?

Mr Chairman with respect, now we're going into all the details of the instructions, we're going into the detail of Brigadier Fikter's instruction and at the end of the day Mr Chairman, I'm concerned that Captain Bokaba is going be prejudiced - I didn't prepare him for the contents of his application, he was not prepared for cross-examination on the contents of his application and if we're going to do that, I'm going to ask ...[intervention]
This surely relates to the credibility of your previous witness?
So why can't you cross-examine your next witness if it reflects on the credibility?

I don't have a problem with that Mr Chairman, but clearly as you all - as you know, you have had extensive evidence about the order structure and specifically the order of Brigadier Fikter and it's not as simple as the question my learned friend ...[intervention]
The question did not relate to Fikter, it related to Loots as to whether Loots gave orders.
Yes, but Mr Chairman, I think the question went further Mr Chairman, but if my learned could repeat the question perhaps then we could deal with that.
Did you get your orders from Loots?
Who did you get your orders from?

Mr Chairman, there we go into the problem because you must remember with Maake, Sefola and Makupi, the evidence was specifically that the whole incident took place under the auspices and the whole general tender of Brigadier Fikter's order.
Mr du Plessis, it's a question of whether he got orders from somebody.  He can tell us who it was.
Let me answer it this way Sir, we received instructions from Hechter.  As to whether - where he received instructions from, I don't know.
Now, you mentioned three incidents, did you get your instructions on each case from Hechter?
We were together with him and we were working with him.  As to where he received the instructions, I don't know.
I'm asking you about your instructions, did you get your instructions in each case from Hechter?

We received instructions from Captain Hechter in all
three incidents.
And besides these incidents, are there any other incidents for which you might have to apply for amnesty in respect of which you made a mistake of not applying earlier on?
Mr Chairman, I object against this question.
What is the point of the question and are you suggesting there are other matters that he hasn't applied for amnesty for?  If so, on what basis?
On the basis of my instructions.
...[inaudible]  should have applied for amnesty on all Ngo's - matters Ngo speaks of, is that what you mean?

That is my point, that there are matters where on my instructions, he should have applied for amnesty and I'm asking him whether he knows of any other incidents for which he should have applied for amnesty.
I made application for amnesty for the three things which I took part in and there are no other incidents which I took part in.
Besides yourself, Selahla and Hechter, who else was involved in these incidents?
Do you mean the three incidents which I'm asking amnesty for?
Mr Chairman, may I beg leave to hand the amnesty application to Captain Bokaba, then he can read to you from the amnesty application exactly who was present in what incident.
Maybe it's not necessary, it is Hechter.
That's even better, let's save time - tell us.
That is Hechter, that's Paul van Vuuren, Joma Masela ...[intervention]
Just one second, we're taking notes.  Paul van Vuuren?
That is Hechter, Paul van Vuuren, Joma Masela and Danny Selahla.
One point I'd like you to clear up before we go on - when did this happen?  The year I'm more interested in not the precise date.
I would say they happened in 1987 if I'm not mistaken.

As the Chair pleases.  It seems the client - the app - the witness is still trying to answer your question, I don't know.  As the Chair pleases, I will proceed.
	Mr Bokaba, do you know if the applicant had been a member of the security branch at Bloemfontein prior to his involvement with Pretoria?

I don't know.  He explained it to me for the first time when we met  that he was an informer.  I started to know that from him, that he was an informer in Bloemfontein, as whether he was a full member of the security branch, I don't know.
And you knew the applicant very well, isn't it?  He lived with you at barracks, isn't it?
Yes, I used to see him at the barracks, I was staying with him at the barracks.
Did you see him at the barracks right through 1987 up to 1989?
I would not say all the time.
But he was living there during 1987 to 1989?
He was staying at the barracks in 1987, that is the time when I said I saw him there.  You won't just always pay surveillance to a person as whether he's asleep or he's not asleep.
But you lived there, didn't you?
Yes, I was staying at the barracks.  Yes, I was staying there at the barracks.
And you met him at the barracks in 1987, isn't it?
I don't know when you say: "we met", what do you mean?
No, don't waste time.  In whatever sense, you met him at the barracks in 1987?
He came to me in - he approached me in 1987 to tell me that he wants to work at the security branch.  We met on that incident.
And during 1988, he was living at the barracks?
I don't remember as to whether he was at the barracks or not.
During 1989, he was living at the barracks?
I don't remember as to whether he was staying at the barracks.
Were you staying at the barracks during '88 to '89?
I was staying at the barracks but at times I was sleeping in the township.
I don't care where you slept at times.  Now, during that time, during '88 to '89, you did not know whether Ngo was living there or not?

Mr Chairman, we have an interest here suddenly in this particular question and I'd like to understand in fairness to Mr Ngo, precisely what the question entails.  I understand the question to
be a statement that Ngo was living at the barracks in 1989.  I would really like my learned friend if possible, to clarify that because that would have ramifications and implications on the evidence of Mr Ngo which he gave before you.   And he's put the question twice on the basis that: "I put to you that Ngo lived in the barracks in 1988 and '89".  
	And you will recall Mr Chairman, that one, evidence has been placed before the Committee that he was on suspension at the time, from the 3rd of January 1989.  He was in Bloemfontein admitted to hospital from the 5th to the 7th of January 1989 and he committed the murder on the 3rd of February 1989, so Mr Chairman, if the question is going to be on the basis of a statement that he lived in the barracks in Pretoria in 1989, we would have an interest in that.
Well, save for the fact that my learned friend is misleading the Committee, there's no evidence that Mr Ngo was suspended, it was suggested to him that he was suspended.
There is evidence before you Mr Chairman, it's in the affidavit - on paper and it is Exhibit P27 and there will be evidence as well Mr Chairman.
Now, will the witness answer the question Sir.
What the counsel asked is, are you putting that Ngo lived there for the whole of 1989?
I did not say so, I said that he was living there during '87 and '89 - '87 up to '89, I did not say that - the entire year.
Well you asked him about ...[inaudible] and as I understood it you asked about '89 as a separate year.
It is an unfortunate misunderstanding but the fact of the matter is that prior to his arrest, he was permanently resident at the barracks in Mamelodi.
Now, could you - you know when your client has been arrested, could you put it to the witness: "up to this day in February or March or April or whenever, he permanently lived at the barracks"?
As the Chair pleases.  Now during 1987 up to 1989, Ngo  - early 1989, Ngo lived at the barracks.
I don't remember and then again, I cannot dispute that he was staying at the barracks.
You see, earlier on you told us that you lived with Ngo.
I said so, yes, then I said February 1987 he approached me that he wants to work at the security branch but from there I cannot remember well and I cannot dispute that he was staying at the barracks.
By the way, when you met - when Mr Ngo approached you for the very, very, very, first time, did you know him before?
I used to see him before but ...[intervention]
Had you spoken to each other before?
Was it also in February when you went - when you took him - yes, you told us the following day you made an appointment with Loots for him to go and see him, isn't it?
Yes, I said that I saw him then, then the following day I made an appointment with Colonel Loots, then I returned, then I took him to Colonel Loots - that is so.
And this was during February 1997 - rather 1987?
And you told us that your application took three months to process from the time you had applied to join the security branch?
I told you that it is so.
And according to the record, Mr Ngo left reaction unit in May 1987?

What records are you talking about?  I don't
understand.  If the records are like that, I don't know.

My learned friend is correct, it is P27, 6.  That is the one that is also at your - I think it's page 65 in the bundle B - 68 Mr Chairman, the last, yes.  I'm not chipping in, I'm just trying to be of assistance so that we can go quicker Mr Chairman.  It's at page 68 of bundle A, the last - B, bundle B, the last entry.
Now, that would have - that is exactly three months from the time when you spoke to Ngo up to the time when he says that he joined security branch.
You said he left security - he left the unit in 1987, according to the records?
Where did you go according to the records?
No, no, I don't answer questions from witnesses, I'm telling you now that, that would be three months after the day when you spoke to him.

Mr Chairman in all fairness, my learned friend should put to the witness that on 18 May 1987, according to the record, he went to the college Hammanskraal Human Resources Management - according to this record on 18 May 1987.
Now, do you see the coincidence?
What in what?  What is coinciding with what?
That it took three months to process your application to join security branch and that it took ...[intervention]
